evidence: This reflects the principle of superposition, which is central to all linear systems.
So shifting in time introduces a phase shift in frequency.
So time-domain modulation causes a translation in the frequency domain.
And the result is scaled by one over the absolute value of a.
Then its Fourier transform reflects across the frequency axis - that is, the transform at minus u becomes the conjugate of the transform at u.
That means the spectrum is symmetric in a complex-conjugate sense.

triples.evidence: If you combine two functions, say f and g, using constants a and b - meaning you form 'a times f plus b times g' - then the Fourier transform of that sum is simply 'a times the transform of f plus b times the transform of g.' This reflects the principle of superposition, which is central to all linear systems.
